questions.question:
A grammar that is both left and right recursive for a non-terminal, is

(GATE CSE 1999)
options:
A.

Ambiguous

B.

Unambiguous

C.

Information is not sufficient to decide whether it is ambiguous or unambiguous

D.

None of the above
questions.correct_answer:
C.

Information is not sufficient to decide whether it is ambiguous or unambiguous
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following is the most powerful parsing method?

(GATE CSE 1999)
options:
B.

Canonical LR

C.

SLR

D.

LALR
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is true?

(GATE CSE 1998)
options:
A.

SLR parser is more powerful than LALR

B.

LALR parser is more powerful than Canonical LR parser

C.

Canonical LR parser is more powerful than LALR parser

D.

The parsers SLR, Canonical CR, and LALR have the same power
questions.correct_answer:
C.

Canonical LR parser is more powerful than LALR parser
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
In the following grammar
\(\begin{aligned} X &::= X \oplus Y \mid Y \\ Y&::= Z * Y \mid Z\\ Z&::= id \end{aligned}\)
Which of the following is true?

(GATE CSE 1997)
options:
A.

'\(\oplus\)' is left associative while '*' is right associative

B.

Both '\(\oplus\)' and '*' are left associative

C.

'\(\oplus\)' is right associative while '*' is left associative

D.

None of the above
questions.correct_answer:
A.

'\(\oplus\)' is left associative while '*' is right associative
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
The grammar whose productions are
\(\langle\text{stmt}\rangle \to\text{ if id then } \langle\text{stmt}\rangle\)
\(\langle\text{stmt}\rangle\to\text{ if id then } \langle\text{stmt}\rangle\text{ else } \langle \text{stmt}\rangle\)
\(\langle\text{stmt}\rangle \to\text{ id }:=\text{ id}\)
is ambiguous because

(GATE CSE 1996)
options:
A.

the sentence
\(\text{ if a then if b then c:= d } \)
has more than two parse trees

B.

the left most and right most derivations of the sentence
\(\text{ if a then if b then c:= d } \)
give rise to different parse trees

C.

the sentence
\(\text{ if a then if b then c:= d else c:= f} \)
has more than two parse trees

D.

the sentence
\(\text{ if a then if b then c:= d else c:= f} \)
has two parse trees
questions.correct_answer:
D.

the sentence
\(\text{ if a then if b then c:= d else c:= f} \)
has two parse trees
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is false ?

(GATE CSE 2001)
options:
A.

An unambiguous grammar has same left most and right most derivation

B.

An LL(1) parser is a top-down parser

C.

LALR is more powerful than SLR

D.

An ambiguous grammar can never be LR(K) for any k
questions.correct_answer:
A.

An unambiguous grammar has same left most and right most derivation
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Choose the correct alternatives (more than one may be correct ) and write the corresponding letters only:
Consider the SLR(1) and LALR(1) parsing tables for a context free grammar. Which of the following statement is/are true?

(GATE CSE 1992)
options:
A.

The goto part of both tables may be different.

B.

The shift entries are identical in both the tables.

C.

The reduce entries in the tables may be different.

D.

The error entries in tables may be different
questions.correct_answer:
B.

The shift entries are identical in both the tables.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

(GATE CSE 1987)
options:

Bottom-up parser.

Top-down parser.

C.

Back tracking parser.

D.

None of the above.
